snippet.textDisplay:
Lalon, also known as Lalon Shah, Lalon Fakir, Shahji, was a Bengali spiritual leader, philosopher, mystic poet and social reformer. Regarded as an icon of Bengali culture, he inspired and influenced many philosophers, poets and social thinkers including Rabindranath Tagore, Kazi Nazrul Islam and Allen Ginsberg. Lalon's philosophy of humanity rejects all distinctions of caste, class, and creed and takes a stand against theological conflicts and racism. It denies all worldly affairs in search of the soul and embodied the socially transformative role of sub-continental Bhakti and Sufism.
Lalon founded the institute known as Lalon Akhra in Cheuriya, about 2 kilometres from Kushtia railway station in southwestern Bangladesh. His disciples dwell mostly in Bangladesh and Indian states of West Bengal, Tripura and Assam’s Barak Valley. Every year on the occasion of his death anniversary, thousands of his disciples and followers assemble at Lalon Akhra and pay homage to him through celebration and discussion of his songs and philosophy for three days.
In 2004, Lalon was ranked 12 in BBC's poll of the Greatest Bengali of all time.
snippet.textOriginal:

Lalon's philosophy of humanity rejects all distinctions of caste, class, and creed and takes a stand against theological conflicts and racism. It denies all worldly affairs in search of the soul and embodied the socially transformative role of sub-continental Bhakti and Sufism.
Lalon founded the institute known as Lalon Akhra in Cheuriya, about 2 kilometres from Kushtia railway station in southwestern Bangladesh. His disciples dwell mostly in Bangladesh and Indian states of West Bengal, Tripura and Assam’s Barak Valley. Every year on the occasion of his death anniversary, thousands of his disciples and followers assemble at Lalon Akhra and pay homage to him through celebration and discussion of his songs and philosophy for three days.
In 2004, Lalon was ranked 12 in BBC's poll of the Greatest Bengali of all time.

snippet.textDisplay:
let me make a few things clear for everyone here:
1. lalon fakir isn't a bangladeshi; he was born in undivided british ruled india. There was no Bangladesh back then 
2. The musicians aren't "foreigners" performing this song
3. The name "India" originates from the Greek word "indos'. Greeks started calling Bharat "India" 1000 years before your prophet was born. 
4. Indian civilization is more than 5000 years old. It's hard for Bangladeshis and Pakistanis to accept that because it gives them identity crisis but it's the hard fact. 
5. It's not Bengalis from india who forgot their root but the east pakistanis who put their religious identity above everything else.
snippet.textOriginal:
let me make a few things clear for everyone here:
1. lalon fakir isn't a bangladeshi; he was born in undivided british ruled india. There was no Bangladesh back then 
2. The musicians aren't "foreigners" performing this song
3. The name "India" originates from the Greek word "indos'. Greeks started calling Bharat "India" 1000 years before your prophet was born. 
4. Indian civilization is more than 5000 years old. It's hard for Bangladeshis and Pakistanis to accept that because it gives them identity crisis but it's the hard fact. 
5. It's not Bengalis from india who forgot their root but the east pakistanis who put their religious identity above everything else.
